docs.lead_paragraph: The F.D.A.’s move to tighten restrictions for prescribing painkillers is a rare victory by lawmakers from states hard hit by prescription drug abuse over well-financed lobbyists for business and patient groups.

headline.main: F.D.A. Shift on Painkillers Was Years in the Making
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Shift on Painkillers Was Years in the Making

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration move to tighten restrictions for prescribing painkillers represents rare victory by lawmakers from states hard hit by prescription drug abuse over well-financed lobbyists for business and patient groups; decision, years in the making, is response to wave of misuse, abuse and addiction that began in late 1990s and has claimed more than 100,000 lives in decade since.
docs.snippet: The F.D.A.’s move to tighten restrictions for prescribing painkillers is a rare victory by lawmakers from states hard hit by prescription drug abuse over well-financed lobbyists for business and patient groups.

byline.original: By BARRY MEIER and ERIC LIPTON

docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when polls show widening public support for legalizing marijuana, California’s 17-year experience as the first state to legalize medical marijuana offers surprising lessons, experts say.

headline.main: Few Problems With Cannabis for California
headline.print_headline: Few Problems With Cannabis For California

docs.abstract: Experts say California's 17-year experience as the first state to legalize medical marijuana offers surprising lessons to the nation at a time when polls show widening support for legalization; research suggests that marijuana has become an alcohol substitute for younger people and that, while driving under influence of any intoxicant is dangerous, driving after smoking marijuana is less so than after drinking alcohol; warnings voiced against partial legalization have proved unfounded.
docs.snippet: At a time when polls show widening public support for legalizing marijuana, California’s 17-year experience as the first state to legalize medical marijuana offers surprising lessons, experts say.

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and RICK LYMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: In a major shift, the Food and Drug Administration recommended new limits on prescriptions for widely abused narcotic painkillers like Vicodin and Lortab.

headline.main: F.D.A. Urging a Tighter Rein on Painkillers
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Urging A Tighter Rein On Painkillers

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration, in major policy shift, recommends tighter controls on how doctors prescribe most commonly used narcotic painkillers, changes that are expected to take place as early as 2014; move follows decade-long debate over whether widely abused drugs like Vicodin and Lortab should be controlled as tightly as more powerful painkillers like OxyContin.
docs.snippet: In a major shift, the Food and Drug Administration recommended new limits on prescriptions for widely abused narcotic painkillers like Vicodin and Lortab.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers, and the premiums are high in areas with the least competition.

headline.main:
Health Care
Law Fails to
Lower Prices
for Rural Areas
headline.print_headline: Health Law Fails To Lower Prices For Rural Areas

docs.abstract: Evidence is emerging that one of health care law's loftiest goals of keeping costs low by encouraging competition among insurers is falling short for many rural Americans; more than half of counties in 34 states on federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers, and premiums are high in areas with least competition.
docs.snippet: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers, and the premiums are high in areas with the least competition.
